title: Hard disk / hot coffee accident - advice needed

forumNotes.author: dmtelf
forumNotes.content:
In the middle of setting up a bootable USB stick, I accidentally spilt about 1cm of hot sugary coffee into the trackpad of my Dell D620 which immediately powered itself down.  

I immediately turned it upside down \& removed the drive caddy. There wasn't any visible liquid on the surface of the HD label side.  

To be on the safe side, the caddy/drive was sandwiched between two very large bags of silica gel which went into a plastic bag for 1 week.  

Now when I connect the HD to an external SATA cradle \& power it on, Windows 7's Disk Manager crashes when loading. It recovers as soon as I turn off the cradle.  

Right now I don't know the extent of the damage to the HD. I need some advice on the best way to progress - should I make a raw image of the HD using TestDisk or..?  

The drive's specs are as below \& I have a separate HD for the raw image:  

Seagate Momentus 7200.2 120Gb  

Model number  
ST9120823AS  

2 disks  
3 heads  
512 bytes/sector  
16,383/16/63 logical CHS  

Thanks.  

DMTelf

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
Are you trying to boot from the hard disk via external SATA? This may not work if it is on a different controller unless you sysprep Windows first (which you cannot do!).  
Why do you think the hard disk was harmed in the first place?  
Why not just put the hard disk back where it was and see if it works?

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Well, to be on the safe side, you should (actually should have): * remove the PCB from the drive * wash it in mildly warm water with a neutral soap * rinse thouroughly in normal water * wash/rinse in distilled water * let it dry
I doubt that any coffee can have actually entered the hard disk mechanical part. You don't specify whether (without being connected to any PC, only powered) the drive spins up normally, any strange noise, etc. Sure, if the disk is functional (even if it has problems connecting it to a Windows 7 through SATA or e-sata) FIRST thing you should do is to image it in a forensic sound manner. You may want to use a USB connection (which is more "forgiving" generally speaking if the device has an issue) and a "plainer" Operating System than Windows7. If you manage to have it working (even if "not recognised" or "need to be formatted") under Windows, you should use Datarescuedd: with THIS approach: ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: dmtelf
forumNotes.content:
> You don't specify whether (without being connected to any PC, only powered) the drive spins up normally, any strange noise, etc. > > Sure, if the disk is functional (even if it has problems connecting it to a Windows 7 through SATA or e-sata) FIRST thing you should do is to image it in a forensic sound manner. > You may want to use a USB connection (which is more "forgiving" generally speaking if the device has an issue) and a "plainer" Operating System than Windows7. > If you manage to have it working (even if "not recognised" or "need to be formatted") under Windows, you should use Datarescuedd: > > with THIS approach: > The disk spins up when connected to an external SATA \<-\> USB cradle (not connected to a PC) \& a colleague has just told me there is a very quiet sequence of 1 beep/squeak, whir, click, repeat. Unfortunately DataRescue DD does not find the drive. I tried testdisk 6.14 \& created a log but it did not find the drive either ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) I looked at the testdisk log, and it found drive F which is a HP Tools partition. Drive G is the laptop's internal DVD drive. What options do I have left with respect to attempting to make a forensic image?
DMTelf --\> Fri Dec 2 12:37:36 2011 Command line: TestDisk TestDisk 6.14-WIP, Data Recovery Utility, November 2011 Christophe GRENIER \ [http://www.cgsecurity.org](http://www.cgsecurity.org "External link") OS: Windows 7 (7601) SP1 Compiler: GCC 4.3, Cygwin 1007.7 Compilation date: 2011-12-01T18:43:19 ext2fs lib: 1.41.8, ntfs lib: 10:0:0, reiserfs lib: 0.3.1-rc8, ewf lib: 20100226 disk_get_size_win32 IOCTL_DISK_GET_LENGTH_INFO(/dev/sda)=500107862016 disk_get_size_win32 IOCTL_DISK_GET_LENGTH_INFO(\\\\.\\PhysicalDrive0)=500107862016 disk_get_size_win32 IOCTL_DISK_GET_LENGTH_INFO(\\\\.\\C:)=481536507904 filewin32_getfilesize(\\\\.\\D:) GetFileSize err Incorrect function. filewin32_setfilepointer(\\\\.\\D:) SetFilePointer err Incorrect function. Warning: can't get size for \\\\.\\D: disk_get_size_win32 IOCTL_DISK_GET_LENGTH_INFO(\\\\.\\F:)=2142240768 filewin32_getfilesize(\\\\.\\G:) GetFileSize err Incorrect function. filewin32_setfilepointer(\\\\.\\G:) SetFilePointer err Incorrect function. Warning: can't get size for \\\\.\\G: file_pread(4,1,buffer,976784129(60801/254/63)) lseek err Invalid argument Hard disk list Disk /dev/sda - 500 GB / 465 GiB - CHS 60801 255 63, sector size=512 - ST950042 0AS, S/N:V5AJD8QM, FW:0006 TestDisk exited normally. --\>

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> a colleague has just told me there is a very quiet sequence of 1 beep/squeak, whir, click, repeat.  
This is NO good news. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png)  

You should use anyway a "more easy" OS than WIndows 7 (namely a Linux) to make sure it is not any of the problems connected to the HAL/UAC/Administrator/whatever, but if the issue is the above, it won't make difference.  

The 7200.2 is a rather oldish drive and most probably you can find if not a donor board, an used disk with a suitable PCB.  
Then you will have to swap the ROM chip, something that is NOT at normal DIY level. ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)  
IF the swap is successful AND IF the ROM data is good, then you should be able to re-access the data.  

This is VERY risky, and there is the risk, by doing the procedure incorrectly, that you "ruin" the drive BEYOND any possible recovery attempt.  

NOW would be the perfect time to decide if your data has a value of several hundreds dollars (the cost of a "pro" recovery) or if not (or you cannot afford anyway that kind of money).  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko
